speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe how long these episodes of unresponsiveness last, and do you experience any warning signs before they occur?

speaker: Patient
text: The episodes last about 3 to 4 minutes. Before they start, I sometimes get a muddy taste in my mouth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Do you recall if there are any specific triggers that seem to bring on these episodes, such as stress, lack of sleep, or certain activities?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really know if there's anything that triggers them. They just seem to happen out of nowhere.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any unusual movements or jerking of your limbs during these episodes, or do you remain completely still?

speaker: Patient
text: I mostly just stare and make some facial grimaces. I don't think I move my arms or legs much during them.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your mood, memory, or behavior outside of these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't really noticed any big changes in my mood or behavior. Sometimes I feel a bit confused after the episodes, but that's about it. My memory seems fine otherwise.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent head injuries or illnesses that could be related to these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any head injuries or illnesses recently. I feel fine otherwise, just these episodes keep happening.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your sleep patterns, such as insomnia or excessive daytime sleepiness?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any trouble sleeping at night, and I don't feel sleepy during the day. I usually sleep pretty well.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any unusual sensations, such as tingling or numbness, before or after these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't felt any tingling or numbness before or after the episodes. It's mostly just the muddy taste and then feeling confused afterward.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever had any similar episodes in the past, or is this the first time you've experienced them?

speaker: Patient
text: This is the first time I've had these episodes. I've never experienced anything like this before.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent changes in medication or started any new medications that could be related to these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't taken any medications or started anything new. I don't use any medicines at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any visual disturbances, such as seeing flashing lights or having blurred vision, during or before these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't seen any flashing lights or had blurred vision before or during the episodes. It's just the muddy taste and then I stare.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any family history of seizures or neurological disorders?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know if anyone in my family has had seizures or anything like that. My parents haven't mentioned it.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your sense of smell or taste outside of these episodes, or is it only during the episodes that you notice the muddy taste?

speaker: Patient
text: I only notice the muddy taste right before the episodes. I haven't had any changes in my sense of smell or taste at other times.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any gastrointestinal symptoms, such as nausea or abdominal pain, during or after these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any nausea or stomach pain during or after the episodes. I feel fine in that way.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your heart rate or breathing during these episodes, or do you feel any physical discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in my heart rate or breathing during the episodes. I don't feel any physical discomfort either, just the confusion afterward.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any unusual fatigue or weakness in your muscles after these episodes, or do you feel normal?

speaker: Patient
text: I feel a bit lethargic and confused after the episodes, but my muscles feel normal. I don't feel weak or anything like that.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent blood tests or neurological evaluations done? If so, what were the results?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any blood tests or neurological evaluations done recently. This is the first time I'm seeing a doctor about these episodes.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you ever experienced any episodes of loss of consciousness or fainting, even if they were brief?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't fainted or lost consciousness at all. I've just been staring and making faces during these episodes.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your appetite or weight recently, or do you feel your eating habits have remained the same?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any changes in my appetite or weight. I eat the same as I always have.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any headaches or migraines before or after these episodes?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any headaches or migraines before or after the episodes. I feel fine in that way.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on your symptoms and the nature of the episodes, I would like to REQUEST TEST: EEG to evaluate for any abnormal brain activity that could indicate seizures.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Electroencephalogram findings show interictal spikes and sharp waves localized to the temporal lobes, more prominent on the right side.

speaker: Doctor
text: Maximum inferences reached

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really understand what those spikes and waves mean. Will I be okay?
